docs.lead_paragraph: Students of supply and demand are familiar with the truism that something is worth whatever you're willing to pay for it. To put a finer point on that, we did a little comparison shopping. JAMIE WALLIS Bruno Frisoni boots ($1,280) = Miele Red Velvet vacuum cleaner ($1,299). Hermès cashmere-and-silk scarf ($921, with tax) = one year of unlimited Metrocards ($912). Luella Pocket Luca in monogram suede ($1,495) = one Belted Galloway heifer ($1,500). Valentino dress ($10,700) = one year of health insurance for a family of four ($10,773). Chanel suit ($4,835) = a dental implant at a Park Avenue dentist ($5,000).

docs.lead_paragraph: Nogaye Sow is a humble street vendor in a rough patch of urban Africa, but hidden in her flowing robe is a weathered piece of cardboard that helps put her on equal footing with those who work in air-conditioned offices instead of at the curb. It is a makeshift health insurance card, with photographs of her, her seven children, her granddaughter and two other relatives pasted inside. When they get sick, they receive free consultations at the clinic down the road, cut-rate medicine and peace of mind. The chances are lower now that a bout of illness will bring the family to total ruin.

headline.main: Neglected Poor in Africa Make Their Own Safety Nets

docs.snippet: Tired of waiting for politicians to address their needs, Africans are creating health insurance cooperatives.

multimedia.credit: Tired of waiting for politicians to address their needs, poor Africans are creating health insurance cooperatives.
multimedia.caption: Making Their Own Safety Nets

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Tired of waiting for politicians to address their needs, poor Africans are creating health insurance cooperatives.

byline.original: By MARC LACEY; Reuben Kyama contributed reporting from Nairobi, Kenya, for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County's discount prescription program has saved residents $3 million on 180,000 prescriptions since it was introduced in July 2004, Howard Weitzman, the county comptroller, said last Tuesday. The average savings were about $17, or 24 percent off retail price, he said. The free program, called Nassau Rx, is meant for people who have no health insurance or who have inadequate prescription-drug coverage, regardless of age or income. Nearly 600,000 Nassau Rx prescription cards have been mailed to county residents. Cards are available by calling (877)321-2652.

headline.main: NASSAU: Drug Savings Estimated At $3 Million for Year

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Anthony D. Weiner proposed yesterday that the city help small businesses band together to bargain for cheaper health insurance. The more small businesses that group together and bargain for a health care plan, the cheaper the plan is likely to be, said Mr. Weiner, one of four candidates in the Sept. 13 Democratic mayoral primary.

headline.main: Weiner Offers His Proposal For Cheaper Health Insurance

docs.snippet: Representative Anthony D. Weiner proposed that the city help small businesses band together to bargain for cheaper health insurance.

byline.original: By ROBIN SHULMAN; Winnie Hu contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: It used to be that a patient with osteoporosis who broke a vertebra was pretty much out of luck. The only recourse was wearing a back brace and waiting to heal. If the searing pain was unbearable, it could be blunted with powerful narcotics. But in the past few years, doctors have been offering and patients demanding what some call a miraculous treatment: vertebroplasty (pronounced vur-TEE-bro-plasty), in which a form of cement is injected into the broken spinal bone.

headline.main: Spinal Cement Draws Patients And Questions

docs.snippet: Doctors have been offering and patients demanding vertebroplasty, a treatment in which a form of cement is injected into the broken spinal bone.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fernando Ferrer proposed yesterday that the city provide universal health insurance for children and expand coverage for adults, seeking to carve out a policy issue that has thus far attracted little attention in the mayoral contest. Speaking at the Betances Health Center on the Lower East Side, Mr. Ferrer, one of the four Democratic candidates, called for health insurance to be provided for the estimated 290,000 children who are now uninsured, and for the at least 200,000 adults who are eligible for coverage but because of language problems or difficult paperwork, currently have none.

headline.main: Ferrer Takes Up the Issue Of Universal Health Insurance
headline.kicker: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: A PROPOSAL

docs.snippet: Fernando Ferrer proposed yesterday that the city provide universal health insurance for children and expand coverage for adults, seeking to carve out a policy issue that has thus far attracted little attention in the mayoral contest.

byline.original: By DIANE CARDWELL; Nicholas Confessore contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Sick and Scared, and Waiting, Waiting, Waiting'' (front page, Aug. 20):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Sick and Scared, and Waiting, Waiting, Waiting'' (front page, Aug. 20):

docs.lead_paragraph: Every time Grace McCabe is handed a form in a doctor's office asking for an emergency contact, the blank space makes her shiver. It is such a simple question for anyone with a spouse, partner or children. But Ms. McCabe, 75, has always lived alone. Who would stand by her in a crisis? Who would be there for her in the worst of times?

headline.main: Alone in Illness, Seeking Steady Arm to Lean On

docs.abstract: Article in series Being A Patient focuses on plight of sick or disabled single people without obvious person to look after them; demographers warn that graying of baby boom generation will swell already growing ranks of single-person households, with illness and disability inevitable corollary of old age; American Hospital Assn official James Bentley says sick people in hospital and afterward need health advocate, and some single persons end up being their own advocates at particularly vulnerable time; says situation is made worse by increase in short stays in hospitals, which sometimes send people home before they can manage alone; people who live alone without obvious next-of-kin for emergency contact forms must rely on patchwork support from professionals and friends; Bentley sees need for hospitals to develop new ways of preparing such patients for what lies ahead and for people who live alone to consider, before they are ill, what organized networks they can call on; cases cited; photos (L)
docs.snippet: People who live alone can end up being their own quarterbacks at a particularly vulnerable time.

multimedia.credit: The number of single-person households in the United States has increased from 2.7 million in 1940 to more than 27 million in 2003, or by more than one thousand percent.
multimedia.caption: Living Alone

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: The number of single-person households in the United States has increased from 2.7 million in 1940 to more than 27 million in 2003, or by more than one thousand percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nicole Sesker sleeps in vacant buildings. She sells her body to buy heroin, living from trick to trick and fix to fix while dodging police officers who chase her from the street corners she haunts in plastic heels. ''I'm a survivor,'' said Ms. Sesker, a petite 36-year-old, in the rough-edged neighborhood of discount liquor stores and boarded-up row houses that she calls home. ''I'm out here surviving.''

headline.main: Police Chief Sees Drug Toll With Father's Eyes

docs.abstract: Baltimore's new police chief Leonard D Hamm is also stepfather of 36-year-old drug addict Nicole Sesker, who has resisted nearly two decades of efforts to help her; Sesker sleeps in vacant buildings, living from trick to trick and fix to fix while dodging police on street corners, lapsing time and again after family's rehabilitation efforts; Hamm, who raised Sesker from age three, says that after nearly two decades of trying to help her he has reached painful conclusion that she will find strength to change only after she sinks even lower; explains department's outreach program for addicts; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The new police commissioner in drug-plagued Baltimore has struggled for years with his stepdaughter's addiction.

multimedia.credit: Leonard D. Hamm, Baltimore's newest police commissioner, has struggled with his stepdaughter's drug addiction.
multimedia.caption: Through a Father's Eyes

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Leonard D. Hamm, Baltimore's newest police commissioner, has struggled with his stepdaughter's drug addiction.

multimedia.credit: Nicole Sesker's story of heroin addiction might not seem remarkable in Baltimore except for one detail: her stepfather is the police commissioner.

byline.original: By JAMES DAO and GARY GATELY

docs.lead_paragraph: Red and white loading cranes loomed like steel sentinels over an empty wharf on a recent afternoon here. Capable of unloading shipping containers at a rate of almost one a minute, these computerized towers often stand frozen for days at a time for lack of ships. Kobe's ranking in world container traffic tumbled to 43rd place last year, from 4th in 1980. Though Kobe's importance as a port started waning in the early 1990's, government bureaucrats responded to the 1995 earthquake here by renovating and expanding the port -- to the tune of $50 billion.

headline.main: Japan's Spending Habit Roils Plan to Sell Big Bank

docs.snippet: Given Japan's dependence on lavish public projects, the proposed sale of Japan Post, a linchpin for government spending, has ignited a political firestorm.
